citation.article-title: Agreia bicolorata gen. nov., sp. nov., to accommodate actinobacteria isolated from narrow reed grass infected by the nematode Heteroanguina graminophila
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Agreia (Ag.reÂ«i.a. N.L. gen. fem. n. Agreia of Agre, named to honour Nina S. Agre, a Russian microbiologist)
Colonies are yellow or yellow-orange in young cultures and can be red-orange or brown-orange with age; round, glistening, opaque, butyrous, sometimes fluid.
Cells are Gram-positive, non-spore-forming, weakly motile, irregularly shaped rods.
Cell wall peptidoglycan is of the B-type and contains DAB and ornithine as diamino acids; hydroxyglutamate may be present instead of some of the glutamate.
The major menaquinone is MK-10, with minor amounts of MK-9.
The principal phospholipids are phosphatidylglycerol and diphosphatidylglycerol.
The major fatty acids are anteiso-15:0, anteiso-17:0 and iso-16:0.
Forms a distinct lineage within the phylogenetic cluster of actinomycetes of the family Microbacteriaceae.
The type species is Agreia bicolorata.
